model_answer: The reticle view shows a crosshair that marks the true celestial pole, which helps align Polaris. To use it, first find Polaris in the sky, then move the reticle so that the crosshair is centered over Polaris. This ensures accurate alignment.

The reason for the sky appearing to return to the same star position after about 23 hours 56 minutes is because of the rotation of the Earth on its axis. The Earth rotates once every 24 hours, but it takes longer for the Sun to appear in the same position relative to the stars due to the Earth's orbit around the Sun. This causes the sky to appear to move across the horizon as the Earth rotates. However, the time it takes for the Earth to complete one rotation is slightly shorter than 24 hours, so the Sun appears to move about 4 minutes ahead of the celestial sphere each day. To compensate for this discrepancy, leap years are added to the calendar to ensure that the calendar year is approximately 365.24 days long, which is close to the actual time it takes for the Earth to make one orbit around the Sun (365.2422 days).
